channel.title: Programming Challenge
channel.description:
Here's moparscape's latest programming challenge. You may use any language you wish.
Embedded in [url=http://challenge.cueup.com/static/gettysburg.txt]this block of text[/url] is the password for level 2. The password is the longest substring that is the same in reverse. As an example, if the input was "I like racecars that go fast" the password would be "racecar".
I'll post my answer later :P Have fun! If you would like to try your hand at the other programming challenges Cue has to offer, check them out at http://challenge.cueup.com/

item.title: Programming Challenge
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“s1gma, post:59, topic:519285”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=637748.msg4304138#msg4304138 date=1369497606]

[quote author=imthenull link=topic=637748.msg4304099#msg4304099 date=1369491501]

[quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=637748.msg4303972#msg4303972 date=1369463475]

nice CFF, i knew a scala solution would be short.
[/quote]I was surprised nobody posted one, so I had to.
[/quote]you’re pretty good at scala, lol
[/quote]Not really… I’m pretty bad at it, seeing there are some concepts in the language that I don’t really understand.

like? i cant imagine there being that much[/quote]The way continuations work throw me through a loop, and I spend a lot of time trying to get them to behave properly; at points I’ve been able to understand them decently, but I tend to regress, seeing I rarely encounter them. Also, I struggle with some of the FP concepts, but those are primarily from libraries like Scalaz.

Also, when I say I don’t really understand them, I mean I can still use them, but I don’t have “mastery” of them.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

2 lines:

val str = "" println((2 to str.size).map(i => try str.sliding(i).find(s => s == s.reverse).get catch { case _ => "" })./:("")((o, n) => if (n.size > o.size) n else o))

There is most likely a more concise way to do this…

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

sinisoul:

Not defending, we’re just not butthurt over the fact that he possibly googled the question and found a valid solution then posted it to show people. He never said it was his, he never said it wasn’t his, and if it is or isn’t the solution is there for people to see in a language not many people are familiar with which is more constructive then posting nothing at all. Take the ego away from this, please. I’m more interested seeing what solutions are there than how fast yours computes the solution, see fat cookies post from earlier in the thread.

You’re missing the point. There was absolutely nothing wrong with him posting that solution, I agree with that. The problem lies in him not crediting the one who wrote it.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:44, topic:519285”]Not defending, we’re just not butthurt over the fact that he possibly googled the question and found a valid solution then posted it to show people. He never said it was his, he never said it wasn’t his, and if it is or isn’t the solution is there for people to see in a language not many people are familiar with which is more constructive then posting nothing at all. Take the ego away from this, please.[/quote]I’m not saying it wasn’t constructive, but if one posts something without giving a source, people are going to assume that person wrote it themselves. It isn’t hard to source a quote.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:44, topic:519285”]I’m more interested seeing what solutions are there than how fast yours computes the solution, see fat cookies post from earlier in the thread.[/quote]I’m not the one who brought speed into this topic, you can blame Enforcer for that. I too wanted to see other people’s ideas for solving the problem, not things copied from Google. If I wanted to see people’s solutions on Google I could have done it myself.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:42, topic:519285”][quote author=John459 link=topic=637748.msg4300734#msg4300734 date=1368940029]

[code=haskell]
text = “”

palindrome str = str == reverse str

substrings [] = []
substrings (x:xs) = substrings’ (x:xs) ++ substrings xs where
substrings’ [] = []
substrings’ (y:ys) = [y] : [ (y:s) | s <- substrings’ ys ]

longest [] = []
longest (x:xs) = if length x > length max then x else max
where max = longest xs

longest_palindrome text = longest (filter palindrome (substrings text))

main = print (longest_palindrome text)[/code]

I didn’t want to post, but I decided to anyway.

This code is not yours, the source of it may be found here: http://blog.lojic.com/2011/03/13/find-longest-substring-palindrome-in-haskell/
[/quote]

None of us really care[/quote]I do. Don’t know why you people are trying to defend someone for possibly taking credit for someone else’s work.

Read full topic
